posts.com: when do you save as .jpg or .png?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413358
.png for images in black and white or very few colors, .jpg for paintings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413358
If file size isn't an issue .png is preferable since PNGs are have lossless compression unlike JPGs. This effectively means if a .jpg is opened and edited multiple times it loses information and degrades in quality.

The reason you would choose .jpg over .png for paintings or coloured work is because of printing, which may not be relevant to your needs. The reason for this is .png is in RGB not in CMYK which is what's used in printing so there is a risk of discrepancy with the colour. There are other ways to address this besides using .jpg and it's very situational, so overall I would still say .png the preferable choice.

please explain these in terms so that a retard can understand
>form
>values
>gesture

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416834
>form
Making a 2d image look 3d by applying perspective.

>value
in the absolute dumbest terms, it indicates a plane change and/or allows the viewer to separate objects from another. See the example. If all the squares were black, it would look like one shape instead of 3 separate shapes. On a single cube, it would indicate the direction the light source.

>gesture
Difficult to understand unless you have some semblance of form. If you combine all of the small shapes of a figure into one large shape, the gesture is essentially the "motion" or curve the large shape is making. Usually this is one big curve called the "line of action" and doesn't necessarily only apply to figure drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6420642 >>6420663
Ok... This is really complicated. I have made hours and coutless of tests about this. The main problem is that the image color profile goes through layers and layers of softwares.

It's all messed up. For instance:
1) The new photo viewer of Windows manages colors in a different way from the old one, which is still installed in the system.
2) A program like CSP does not use color management (you can use the color proof, but the color picker will be wrong).
3) On Windows you can add the color profiles as "advanced color profile", but no one knows what it does because there is not a documentation about it (avoid this setting).

The more I test stuff, the more I get headache. I have just setted everything as sRGB IEC61966-2.1, and when I save the image, I save it without embedding the color profile and coverting it to sRGB (the coversion should be useless because I worked already in sRGB color space). I'm sorry that I can't really answer.

Also, an unrelated thing. Stuff about color proof in grayscale and gamma.
https://gregbenzphotography.com/luminosity-masking/how-to-optimize-your-gray-working-space-for-better-luminosity-masks/
https://youtu.be/tkAW9u2fZGY

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423798
vanishing points with enclosed scenes are kind of tricky. if they're far enough you can kind of estimate them without much issue. if you work in digital you can zoom out quite far and add guidelines, but i'm not sure how practical it'd be in traditional.
what i find helpful, is often things will share horizon lines. for example, if you wanted to rotate an object that's otherwise in a one point perspective scene, the point itself would be in a different place, but it'd share it's horizon with that first point (i visualise this as it sliding along the horizon line). if it was rotated vertically, i'm not sure if there's a vertical equivalent to a horizon, but you'd essentially do the same thing above/below the "main" vanishing point.
it being rotated both horizontally and vertically starts to get a bit complicated. if you're struggling with perspective, don't worry about this for now
a character or figure would generally share it's vanishing point with the scene, but it depends. as it's more organic and rounded vs a cube or object, i wouldn't worry about it too much as long as the horizon/viewpoint looks okay and is generally consistent with the rest of the scene. the other anon's suggestion about drawing them in a box can be helpful to get a feel for it/keep them in scale.
i think this can be hard to visualise with text alone, lmk if you need any clarification or examples and good luck

In english, crayon means a stick of chalk or wax. Like picrel.
In French, it means "pencil". Think regular pencil.

Looking at this drawing, it looks like it was made using wax pastels (close to picrel too). Fancy art shop will have dry pastels and wax pastels. Personally, I prefer the wax ones, the dry ones are closer to colored charcoals. You can also mix the two!
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crayon
Hope you have fun with trad drawing, anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423798
Just imagine enclosed scenes as if you're inside a "box", logically if the structure has right angles it converges somewhere in the horizon line, if you need visualize it, instead of working on an enclosed canvas, create a frame for your piece, then create this big box in 2pp that expands outside of the frame, you'll have already decided where your eye level or horizon line is, then just place each vanishing point where you want them to be, this is for your box, and any other object that aligns with said box.
Basically, your creating a box where things are going to sit, then you'll play camera man and adjust what you want to show on the plane. You can freehand it first then do a small/medium sketch with accurate perspective then blow it up in whatever size you're actually doing the painting. A common mistake for people doing perspective is they start big and go straight at it without any idea at the blank page, from experience it simply doesn't work and you'll get frustrated and will end up rushing it/stopping.
Perspective drawings are harder because they deal with more elements in the plane, so you'll you have to break it down in steps, plan your painting, get some dirty small sketches out first, if you're doing it trad they can be 5x7 cm, in digital something like 640x480 will do, you can use a big canvas and create a few squares for these sketches, you'll have room for the box process (you may end up not doing this anymore in the future, but it has a few other uses anyway) and you'll be doing different iterations right there, and you can get them out quick. Using reference is also suggested, just don't go blind expecting to create a final result right off the bat if you have no mental image or an idea of how things actually look like.
Also watch Vandruff's 1994 perspective lectures, it deals with different kind of measurement systems that may be useful for you, like projecting measurements on space based on translating divisions from 2D measurements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6424704
Don't ctrl+Z too much. A "correct" line isn't necessarily a good one.
I don't know if that's your case, but drawing lines very timorously like you're performing open heart surgery is generally what makes them feel dead. If you zoom in on a high res versions of drawings you like, you'll probably find a lot more overlaps and small gaps than you would've thought.
That's not to say you should be careless, just that you shouldn't sacrifice what looks good for what you think would be proper.
If you have trouble getting out of the mindset of just tracing the sketch try lowering the opacity more, gaussian blurring it, or changing the colour if you don't do that already.

>>6433923
"gesture drawing" as an activity is a huge meme. It comes from Nicolaides, who couldn't draw for shit.

"Gesture", on the other hand, refers to the pose of the figure. Animators focus on this a lot because the posing and mannerisms of the figure is their whole job. Comic artists and storyboard artists also focus on acting a lot too.

The "gesture" is not a series of wobbly lines. I like Vilppu, but he really created a lot of confusion when he refers to the gesture as a specific thing you do, and not as one aspect of your finished drawing. Proko and Hampton also jumped on this stupid train of thought too. Steve Huston's a bit out there with his "gesture" as "long axis"

tl;dr, just focus on figure drawing, learning construction, anatomy, and loosening up of your poses. Gesture drawing is a /beg/ trap

>>6432744
I'm the same (ADHD and chronic procrastinator). It's like I can't physically move towards the drawing tablet. I procrastinate because of my perfectionism and I'm a perfectionist because of my rigid upbringing and other shit.

Found out, at least in my case, that that's an emotion regulation problem. Acceptance and Commitment Therapy is helping me. I had the belief that I needed to be all happy, content, motivated and with no anxiety at all to start working, but that's not true.

My anxiety is part of the alarm system of my mind trying to stop me from getting into another situation where I didn't achieve what I set out to do and got psychologically hurt. It just wants to protect me by keeping me in that comfort zone. It's like an overprotective mother that's afraid of letting her daughter get out of the house.

I stopped fighting against the anxiety. "Ok, I know you're just trying to protect me. Thank you. But I'm not you. I'm just feeling you and you're just an indicator, not a requirement. I can still act towards my long-term goals even when feeling you. I won't try to push you away, but I'm also not required to obey you."

You should take a look at ACT. It's good shit.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GnSHpBRLJrQ

I realized I was suffering from information overload. I'd wake up at 5 AM and go to bed at 10 PM and my mind wouldn't get a single second's rest. I'd jump from social media to Netflix to my work to social media again to reading something to listening to a podcast to thinking about the future to do some shit around the house etc.

My mind never had time to process and absorb all that shit I was cramming into it and it started giving me anxiety and a lack of focus as a cry for help.

I slowed way the fuck down and purposefully set some time blocks to do absolutely nothing, just lounge or stare out a window, shit like that. Let me tell you, my cigarette count went way down lmao

>>6434762
I can relate to everything you've said.
I'm also a perfectionist due my upbringing. I have brutal and straight up unfair standards for myself. I am genuinely disappointed when I underachieve. I'm too scared to start because I might not fulfill the high expectations I have for myself.
I'm scared of failing which triggers my anxiety hard.
Having high expectations and seeing art as work where I need to get results and not as something I get joy out of is one of the things I still struggle with.

But I've also learned during therapy not to fight against my anxiety.
I used to get extremely frustrated and angry at myself when I messed up and had an anxiety attack or when an unpleasant thought about the past popped up.
I've essentially had become my own bully and had continually shamed myself for my actions and inactions in the present and past.
Life is already hard enough, so why should I make it even harder by not working together with my thoughts and emotions?
My own body is not my enemy.
My thoughts and anxiety aren't panic alerts, they're reminders.
A reminder is not a cause to panic.

I have to keep reminding me of this fact everyday or else I slip into dooming again.

posts.com:
>>6366575
>spend more than 10 minutes
All my drawing attempts are agonzingly slow as I spend ages deliberating every single line. I can't imagine getting something done in only ten minutes.
>pick an easier subject
I genuinely don't understand what supposedly makes a subject easier or harder to draw. Everything past basic geometric shapes/forms seems impossibly difficult. I've seen people claim that rocks and trees are easy, which seems crazy to me given that they have such incredibly complex shapes and textures.
>copy literal lines and squares that you drew
I can copy drawings without much issue. The difficulty of drawing for me isn't in measuring or line placement, but in figuring out how the subject could be depicted as a drawing in the first place. I don't have an intuitive understanding of what I'm supposed to be marking with lines, or a clear idea of what process people actually use to draw things. I can also never mentally picture what a drawing of any particular subject would look like. As such, there's very little actually guiding my efforts, which is presumably why I always end up with bizarre indecipherable scribbles.

>>6367712
I had similar problem, but I generally solve it in the canvas, and I let fuck ups ignite more ideas, if I can't picture it, time to look at refs and do some iterations. A good exercise is picking an object like a banana, observe it for a minute, notice the contours, textures, distinctive shapes, now get rid of the banana and draw it as you recall, take your time. Now a copy of it now, check the differences between the 2 drawings.

Some cheap workaround for coming up with something is creating a square in an isometric angle, and just put stuff some simple subjects in it, or you can do it with wonky perspective, but keep a basic angle of view, use your room as reference if you want. Like looking at your desk and pretend that's a little village you're looking at. If you're autistic you can make dioramas too. Also try sculpting, even plastiline is good enough, it's just to start to get you thinking spatially, you need to develop that awareness to think above just abstract lines into a white void, if you need an extra push rely on reference for ideas and details.
Even for awareness you need awareness, it's not just about aping things, but being present, if you have different perspectives you've got yourself better odds at solving problems in your art process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The only "masteries" are

>line quality

>Perspective

>Anatomy

>Values


Line quality is the best to learn first, deciding what's thick and what's thin, using lines to imply the shape instead of perfectly tracing it out. Anatomy is next, its just measurements. The head is as complex as the entire body, but the key is consistency. Perspective is being able to rotate what you drew and draw it in another angle, usually a more interesting one. Values are colors and shading.

There are things like composition which I would call a mastery but its something you can learn the entire time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I will translate the OP's chart into words for you autists, with some additional neg levels:

level -2: cant draw lines of any sort , and cannot draw shapes
level -1: can draw lines and simple shapes
level 0: multiple shapes that look human, but fill no 3d space and are not proportional
level 1: proportional and symmetrical
level 2: a minimum understanding of 3d space
level 3: a more complex pose (limited to frontal, 3/4 view, profile)
level 4: Even more complex pose, includes other normal viewing angles - any angle that is not frontal, 3/4, or profile, more subtle control elements.
level 5: Starting to add more extreme perspective control - frogs eye view, birds eye, ants eye, fish eye, perspective and scenery
level 6+: impossible to tell from a single image - history of being "in control of style" with the ability to duplicate/replicate whatever styles the person likes.

Also take the other chart that goes with that one.

>>6421995
yeah, that chart is probs a bit of a rough read for a beg. but a useful concept it outlines is that you can 'level up' different technical drawing skills independently of each other to an extent. whereas in your framework, one might get the impression that any sort of aptitude in one of your levels implies mastery over previous levels.

>>6424819
>>6426198
this anon here (or maybe these are 2 different anons) thinks that their image is at 'level 2 or 3' because it displays a 'minimum understanding of 3d space'. which it actually totally does. but that doesn't mean they've mastered drawing simple shapes, a 'level -1' skill. or that they can draw proportionally or symmetrically, 'level 1'.

the chart outlines that, in reality, you can work on all of these proposed levels at the same time, and depending on your needs and the types of images you wish to draw, focus more on some than others.

pic related is from this artists' twitter who works in a very flat, graphic style:
https://twitter.com/WarwickJC/media
I think a failing of the chart, as well as your own framework, is that they're not able to adequately classify an image like this, clearly pro level work, that isn't leaning on crazy 3d space manipulation or anatomical knowledge.
largely because of the types of images the creator of the graph is interested in drawing: like anime pin ups or whatever. to be fair I think they admit this themselves.
Just useful to let begs know that really strong line and shape confidence, with mastery over proportion, symmetry and other 'low level' skills can lead to a 'pro level' image like the one we see here.
(also, you can see on this guy's twitter that he does have mastery over 3d space, and I'm sure he also has mastery over anatomy and all that figurative good stuff. you can certainly find artists and graphic designers who haven't felt the form, not even once, but have a really strong sense of shape, leading to pro level work. probably not figurative stuff though.)

>>6431321
I don't think you need to focus on any one art fundamental. rather just be conscious of the fact that there's infinite room for growth along any of the art fundamentals, you can always push the horizon.

Right now, it's really not the case that any one of your art fundamentals is significantly stronger than any other, no use putting one on the back burner. you're gonna have to keep focusing on all of them and let a year or so pass before you evaluate strengths and weaknesses again.

You'll need books and courses on perspective, figure drawing, composition. find them in the artbook thread or video course thread, maybe. there should be stuff marked for begs right?
do a very small amount of hoarding, peruse over what you have and start following along with whichever courses seem to produce images similar to ones you'd like to produce right now.
Then it's just a matter of drawing a lot

as for this:
>So basically I should learn how to draw simple shapes (like squares and circles (without perspective) ) and draw things proportionate or symetrical
My advice: put your mind in that of a teenage girl. they're very powerful at drawing hearts and stars and things. because their diaries are full of that stuff, boys names they like wrapped in multiple hearts with arrows and shit flying out of them. and every time they write jason's name they'll try to make the hearts more prettier and have the stars twinkling more pika-pikaly, do you get what I'm saying? consider the sheer tonnage of symmetric shapes they're pumping out and making conscious effort to improve upon. there's no burning out here. there's always another boy on the horizon, and viscerally, they need the hearts to be more symmetric, VISCERALLY. like the need you have to beat off, I'm serious.
so don't break your neck drilling this shit. find chill ways of repeatedly drawing shapes that conform to your own personality. just another instance of finding ways to apply fundies to shit you personally care about.

>>6434187
>But you didn't create the tool, you didn't train it off your own art either
But that would apply to any tool then.
Did you create the pen and paper or tablet you're using?
Do the people that have created your tool actually have the rights to whatever you created with them?
>Free users don't get copyright. Paid users get transfer of copyright.
That's a legal issue, but based on the current laws, anything you create (if unique) you automatically hold the intellectual rights to it.
Copyright is another beast entirely that also implies distribution and usage rights (as in marketing, branding, etcetera).
>Training off of non-public domain images is another issue altogether, and there will be lawsuits soon to settle it one way or another.
That's another case entirely that cannot be discussed without the current, concrete proof and all the context around it.
If i say, i bought for access to an artists patreon, i automatically have the right to use the pictures as long as i don't distribute it or sell it, hence i can use it to train an algorithm to generate similar images, as per current law.
In the domain of copyright/intellectual property law, a style cannot be protected, only each individual work created is protected and belongs to the creator.
If it weren't this way, no one but the "firsts to create a style" would be allowed to produce and sell art.

The lawsuits could be very well end up doing absolutely nothing because the laws are there already and if they decided to ban AI for the sole reason of being a tool that makes a job better than the artist, then you will see governments getting sued and losing all credibility.

>>6434210
>But that would apply to any tool then.
Tool's don't create automatically create art by themselves, but the process of creating a tool could be considered art. Humans use tools to create art, but in this case the tool itself generates all of it by itself. If the tool does nearly all the work how much effort has the prompter put in?

The majority of existing artists and a lot of their followers don't consider that to be the case. This isn't the fine art where technique and effort are considered to be trade and not art, this is the mass online consumption art scene where public opinion of the masses dictate rules that artists and companies follow voluntarily if they want to participate. Current prevailing opinion is that effort does factor into art, and thus prompting alone would not be considered effort enough for the prompter to get receive the recognition for the art the tool generated.

>Did you create the pen and paper or tablet you're using?
I can create the charcoal and parchment to draw if absolutely needed to. Even a photographer could setup a pinhole camera and makeshift film if they didn't have access to a modern camera. If a prompter didn't have access to the AI tool could they do anything? An Artist is more than just the tools they use.

>Do the people that have created your tool actually have the rights to whatever you created with them?
Depends on the agreement. For Starcraft 2 and Warcraft 3 reforged Blizzard put in its TOS that they own all intellectual property in addition to the maps created in the editor. Haven't been tested in court yet AFAIK but these things do exist.

>if they decided to ban AI for the sole reason of being a tool that makes a job better than the artist, then you will see governments getting sued and losing all credibility.
They could just make training via AI on copyrighted materials illegal. Just pay for the rights.

>>6415721
>>6416200
I start off either with a bean or a trapezoid for the torso and turn it into a precise and coherent 3d shape. Then I add flat shapes for neck and limbs and slowly work myself through carefully connecting them with bracketing and flesh them out afterwards. It takes a little longer that way, but in the end it's 15 times faster because I don't have to do endless corrections afterwards. What's great about it is it finally lets me control the bendyness of the torso like I want to, and having a clear direction where the arms are in 3d space. Here's my practice sheet from today exploring a little more.

>>6424335
You're getting conflicting advice. I'm doing bridgman copies from memory rn. Here's my two cents, and I'm posting my work (bridgman from memory). If I'm contradicted by a better artist, so be it.
>stop doing timed exercises
These are not useful for a beginner. Do it right before you do it fast.
>roughly learn the proportions of the human body
You don't have to learn every last detail but from your sketches you're having huge issues with proportion. Learn the chart for a male and female standing, 7.5 or 8 heads tall (bridgman uses 7.5, that's what I go with). Be able to draw it from memory, use graph paper if you have to. Again, just get a rough idea, since figure drawings will often be in perspective or bent etc. But if you don't even know how long the legs are supposed to be in relation to the torso, that will reflect in your work, so get a hold of that.
>Michael Hampton's Figure Drawing: Design and Invention
Read the chapter, copy the sketches in that chapter, reproduce the sketches from memory, then try some on your own from photo reference. GOOD photo reference, not porn or social media selfies. Do a lot of standing poses that emphasize contrapposto so you get a good feel for weight. Don't neglect feet, ground your figures. Don't worry about hugely foreshortened figures or sitting/lying figures for now, just internalize the idea of the spine and weight-bearing leg.
>Pit stop: boxes and cylinders
After doing the gesture chapter of Micky Hamps, before you move on, make sure you're somewhat comfortable with drawing boxes and cylinders in perspective. You don't have to be Erik Olsen, but get a good feel for it as well as wrapping simple solids and organic forms with cross-contour lines as well.
cont...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6429943
>Finish mickey hamps's book
Keep going through the book by reading the chapter, copying the sketches, reproducing them from memory, and then trying them from GOOD photo reference. Supplement your anatomical knowledge with a good anatomy book. Goldfinger, Morpho, Stonehouse, Anatomy for Sculptors, doesn't really matter just pick one. I like morpho because it's small and the "willowy" morpho figures complement Bridgman's boxier, stouter ones later on.
>Bridgmarathon
Now it's time for the big boy: copy bridgman twice (skipping the heads section) just like Daddy Finch told you. Since I'm here I won't go any farther than this, but my plan after finishing Bridgman is to brush up on my portraiture by doing the "copy twice" method with Loomis' faces book.

>>6416749
(Clockwise order)
So-bin
Murata
Atmosphere sketchbooks has sketches from I think 3 artists
Settei Dreams has artbooks and storyboards of anime
Horikoshi has sketches
And Inoue Kiyoshirou has an "artbook" which is just the sketches of a hentai he drew.

In the end, you won't find many "artbooks" like the yoshinari one especially of artists' sketches. Mostly finished work which you said you're not looking for.
Also, don't limit to just artbooks, copy directly from manga too.(Which is how most mangakas got good.) since they're basically just clean sketches

Lastly, don't hoard books, I recommend copying front to back 1 at a time before moving onto the next one every single week.
Hope I helped ;)

Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:

>>6432980
i wouldnt listen to that guy who was trying to give u advice. the hair goes dark enough. the darkness of your shadows depend on the ambient light in the area, which is a lot of light based on the rest of your figure and how dark the shadows go everywhere else. you can darken them, but thats mostly for design purposes, composition, to make shapes WITH the darks. but if thats not what you are going for, then its ok to have shadows that dont go way dpp, your shadows are ok as they look, value wise, unless again, you are trying to make composition with your shadows like i did with my composition sketch here
>>6433103
but the mood of your painting is not like that. lighting determines mood. if you want a serious mood, go for dark shadows, if you are doing cute anime girls, you dont need strong dark shadows and dramatic cast shadows and shit. it looks ok.

to answer your question about the "problem" your having with the hair, unless you articulate it another way i dont see a problem. the most important thing is that the hair looks natural and it fits to the painting, if it didnt fit it would look like it was cut out of a magazine or something. but it works, honestly it looks fine and matches the rest of your painting in terms of lighting, values and brushwork so i wouldnt worry about it. hair DOES get dark, because its reflective, but you went dark enough as far as im concerned.

>draw from a reference with heavy perspective

>>6428944
>I just keep jumping from book to book everytime I can't copy the illustrations and I'm losing my mind
That’s kind of the heart of the problem, isn’t it? It honestly doesn’t really matter what resource you pick to learn from as long as you consistently work through the material and don’t just jump ship if you don’t get it right at first. Failure is an inherent part of learning so your best bet is to just power through the failures until you succeed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428944
Just do Bargue plates. It's slow and tedious busywork but it'll teach you relative measuring and train your eye so you can catch your mistakes more easily and play spot the difference between your study and the original better.
Don't binge the whole thing, just a bit everyday. It's fucking boring but it works, and once you have a good eye for proportions and accuracy studying is easier.
You actually plateau pretty fast when only drawing as a hobby with little to no studying like most people did as children/teens. Deliberate practice is the only way anyone improves, but if you don't draw for fun and don't mix studying with drawing what you like you'll be miserable and burn out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428944
if you're having eyeballing issues, try practicing with graph paper and overlaying a grid on your reference to match and have it side by side to match. instead of tackling an overwhelming amount of detail at once, you break it down by matching the lines/details on the smaller squares.

pic related. it should help your sanity a bit since you'll see progress as long as you're autistic about the accuracy of the line placements in the squares.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428960
That sounds like a nice, good practice
Thank you! I'll keep it in mind

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428973
no problem. as you advance you can enlarge those squares until eventually it's 4x4 or none at all. the key is to be super autistic about line placement to train your accuracy. good luck.

What is /ALT/?
If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.
>Rules & Guidelines
(1) Any form of cartooning is welcome; so submit and receive feedback from others. (2) Please resize your images before posting. (3) Share your knowledge and (4) Remember to not be afraid of asking for critique. Most importantly, keep discussion at a civil level
>I came for anime. Why does the image OP say cartoons general?
To distinguish from the anime study thread (janitor supported). Please post your studies there and personal work goes here.
------
>Community Resources
>Tag the OP if you want a resource included here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Resolution thread. What size canvas do you paint with and what is the best resolution to print digital art? How does one go about choosing the best canvas size?
If I want to be able to print in a A0 format max, will a 9000px (ish) canvas do it? Will I be able to scale it down without losing too much quality if afterwards I want to print in a smaller format?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6429385
DPI is most important when looking at print. Usually 300 will suffice but 600 dpi I hear is used for large posters.

Canvas size is dependent on what you're doing. Sketching you can away with anything where you don't see pixelations. Any kind of line work I'd recommend at least 4000 if not 6000.

Painting I'd cater to your hardware. You can always start small at like 1000 and gradually scale up as you add details. You don't want to start large since if you start using huge brushes on a 5000 size canvas, your hardware may lag. But its ultimately what your hardware can handle.

>>6428206
>try making the head slightly smaller than usual
please stop doing this—I don't know why undersized heads are so popular with artists who draw this body type because it's not as if your head shrinks when your body gets heavier. Microcephaly is not a marker of "fertility." The most important things to remember are where the clavicle/shoulders, ribcage, and hips have ended up, because they're all covered now with fat but still determine where masses like the breasts, belly, thighs are going to sit. And knowing where those are will help keep the head proportionate when you are sketching; not knowing I assume is why it shrinks more often than not with these artists.

who is this? Your attempt is not terrible. Mostly lacking in various comparable proportion and perspective zones. Digital is how I prefer to practice likenesses because you can notice your mistakes further in the piece and its not over/ easy to correct. But that does not mean one should get lazy with their initial block in of shape.

>>6434697
How does one learn to make a loose sketch? I have yet to encounter a resource that really explains any sort of sketching, or even the concept of going from a rough drawing towards a more finished one (beyond a few that have said "this is a thing artists do" but offered no further explanation.) Everything I've read has instead been focused on accuracy and twenty different ways to measure, and how to treat drawing like it was brain surgery. I would really like to find a drawing method that doesn't involve spending 10-15 minutes analyzing a potential line before placing it, which is all that I've learned so far.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434734
Looseness is by it's very nature hard to teach. There isn't just one way to do it. What works for me is drawing very lightly initially, not paying attention to accuracy and proportions. Then I gradually darken the correct lines. It's really hard to explain. Try doing it for a while. Maybe it will click on it's own for you, the way it did for me.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6434757
Draw what you have access to from life. For anatomy and portraiture you can use photos. Doing master studies can be one of the most beneficial things for you. It's like you're being taught by the greats themselves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434782
Like I said it’s mostly things available on my property. I suppose that’s helpful for understanding interiors and nature and the like, but it’s not like drawing a parked lawnmower imparts skills that transfer to drawing alien spacecraft.
By master study, you mean replicate other artwork? I do that already on occasion, I pick random panels from manga, try to mirror it in my head, and then draw that mirrored image on the page. I figure mirroring it helps me understand the lines I’m drawing better, rather than ‘cargo cult’-ing the work. Is that good, or a waste of time?
I’ve heard drawing from photographs isn’t good because you miss out on the dynamism and depth inherent in actual living models.

I’ve wondered how manga artists come to develop their styles. Why is it that kids in Japan naturally draw their cartoons in such a wildly different way? What books do they read, and techniques do they practise? There are millions of ‘self taught’ manga artists who just doodled and it still comes out looking Japanese in a way no western artist replicates fully. even the small things like poses, expressions, wingdings/accents, shading and lighting are distinctly different. I’ve been reading on traditional Japanese philosophy and classical art to try and understand the secret sauce of their society that makes it, but I still feel like I’m nowhere close.

Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Recommended Resources:

>>6426634
Not at all. You need to have marks down so you have a point of comparison. Here's a video of one of Krenz's students copying simple line drawings:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iK5Qn_Iwv9A
Accuracy, specially as a beginner, isn't about getting things exactly right the first time, but being patient and correcting things until you do. With time your eye for proportions and relative distances will get better, but even pros have to double-check and correct their initial assumptions from time to time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6426824
As long as you're actually comparing the distances and measuring you'll get something out of it. In real life people have to be more thoughtful about checking since it takes way longer to do, but in both cases comparing with the original is the only way to know if you have the "right answer".
It might be a good idea to only check once you're done with a stage of blocking-in, and then correct as needed until you can move on. If you check after every line or every other line it really would be pretty close to mindless.
Being ambitious is a good attitude, the upper half looks very nice. If you combine accuracy with studying volumetric drawing you can understand the subject better and get more out of artist studies.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6426949
I just mean drawing with 3D volume in mind. The folds on the sleeves, for example, come across as random marks and don't have any form.
Depicting form with only line is very difficult, but things don't suddenly flatten out when they're in frontal or side view. Seeing how others can create the illusion of volume even under those constraints is one of the reasons to do master studies.
Training accuracy is mostly about 2D observations like relative proportion, but if you're studying an image that depicts 3D form you'll miss out on a lot if you don't keep those aspects in mind and analyse them too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428305
Chicken scratching just means drawing a billion little lines to build up one hard to read, hairy-looking line. This is bad because it makes the drawing confusing even to the person who drew it, and fucks up your perception making it harder to see the form.
Restating a line to refine a shape or guessing what you want your composition or pose to be with light lines before committing to a darker one is regular sketching behaviour and an extremely common way of drawing.
Warosu still has archived images, use it to check out this older thread chock-full of timelapses:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't want to seem overly critical, but I feel that the standard way to draw anime is a bit misguided.

Those early animations from which anime is derived were worked on by talented illustrators and painters. But the reason why their output was relatively extremely simplistic wasn't because they didn't desire accurate paintings, but because it would have taken a hundred years to make every frame realistic.

The lineart-and-bucket-fill method was not the desired outcome, but was the most efficient way to drop down shape and definition. If you are not aiming for that one-frame-a-minute pace, I think it would be better to paint your anime, than to draw it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6430997
It's hard to present a thesis when you have a 1000 character limit.

It was merely an observation from doing some research on old animation stuff that the vast majority of anime ever made was made by simplifying a complex subject, outlining the simplification, and filling color inside the lines. This style was a necessity because of time and money constraints, and is the source of "Anime style".

This contrasts with what I've seen recommended for "How to draw Anime", where they tell you to do overly complex style-copying or construction on your favorite anime, when that isn't likely how the original artist made it, or how the original artist would have preferred to make it.

This was not meant to be an attack on others' preferred methods of making art. I just thought it overly complicated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6431107
>This style was a necessity because of time and money constraints, and is the source of "Anime style".
Anime isn't the only medium which does that. Manga, comics, bandes dessinés, etc also do.
This end result doesn't look as such solely due to process behind, it's also due to it being an efficient way to convey meaning and incite emotions in the viewers in an artistic and archetypal manner which can resonate with our brains in way reality/realism cannot, I think. As in, less details isn't entirely about making the work easier, it's also about getting to the essence of things more straightforwardly.

>This contrasts with what I've seen recommended for "How to draw Anime", where they tell you to do overly complex style-copying or construction on your favorite anime, when that isn't likely how the original artist made it, or how the original artist would have preferred to make it.
That's an interesting remark. For that I think we need to study the kind of people who tend to try and replicate things in such a thorough manner and get why they do so.
The original artist doesn't make it as such because it's innate to them, it's what the different parts of their mind end up producing altogether.
For someone trying to copy it stems from them feeling like what they see is what they want to ingrain. It's like a mirror image which mirrors some sort of sum of what they internally value, or getting close to it at least. Such people who are very sensitive to this internal process have a hard time letting lose and drawing something they internally value negatively since the result they see ends up being linked to their self-worth, which is discouraging. So to sprout motivation they end up making these "overly complex style-copying/construction" in order to slowly rewrite this physical habit within themselves in a way which feels good to them.
Eventually they'll be able simplify the construction the more the target style is "achieved" (cont)

>It looks particularly bizarre to have the canvas and wood fins coming out of heavy iron/steel/whatever.
they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas
>also... why does it have regular ship screws?
because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)
>Show pipes or... something to differentiate from regular hull

This thread gave me all I needed to know about this board. It's full of people with no talent or abstractist thinking who spend years and years trying to fit into being an artist, Or Illustrator or anything. They work hard or work for a long time to become this thing they want to be however because of this they become cynical, jaded, Do they truly love it? Are they creators, Artists or just people who can draw very well.
They spend a lot of money and time on the BEST NEW equipment thinking it will make them better and it does produce a better product but at the end of the day, there are two realms when it comes to professions like these (To put it simply, Call them abstract and then traditional) and one needs to respect the other whichever they reside in
It's much like /mu/ when you post music.
Your art is awesome OP, whoever this is. The use of white is incredibily impressive . I'm always interested in art that needs to be closely looked at and when I draw, sometimes I try to draw something that is a bit "tricky" to discern what it truly is, Opening the work to multiple interpretations other than the artists.

Depends on where you’re at, skill-wise and what your goals are. But in order from when I started to now, some books I’ve found helpful are:
Vilppu drawing manual, along with the video lectures
Simultaneously, The first 10-20 pages of any book on perspective to give you a rough idea of 1,2 ,3 point perspective to aid you in the goal of drawing boxes using intuition.
Hampton
Anatomy for sculptors
That Tom fox anatomy book is pretty cool.
And lots of copying art from your favourite artists. And lots of figure drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434338
NTA but yes and no. This is a subject I'm very familiar with and I get paranoid about a lot.
There's a lot to one's own psyche that you'll never be able to analyze properly and will influence your writing style beyond possible conscious recognition, so yes AI will do a better job identifying you than you can imagine.
However, looking at the entire internet, it's not that easy to identify one guy. There's a lot of other people out there with identical writing styles to you. Human language has a finite number of possible combinations. Double however, applying a filter to limit your search makes the technology a much greater danger.
For an example, if someone had your twitter history to build a model from, knew you posted on 4chan, had a specific time frame, limited their scope to archives of /pol/, maybe even a specific thread, then the number of distinct people they're picking from is a few thousand. a few hundred, or much less. They could get your posts with existing technology, assuming you're not a schizophrenic psychopath who makes an effort to write like a different person depending on what platform you're using or what part of your ideologies you're expressing. But probably only for posts of like 40 words or more, odds increase with word count obviously.
It's possible for humans to do this too, you've seen posts you can immediately identify as some specific schizoposter, like this one, if you browse the right boards you already know who I am. No AI required.
tl;dr The future won't actually be that much worse than the present, but the present is worse than you know, we're not waiting on technology for author recognition to cancel you, just for someone to make it an app.

>James Gurney: Imaginative Realism: How to Paint What Doesn't Exist
>Francis Tsai: 100 Ways to Create Fantasy Figures

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428274
Just got this, extremely disappointing compared to the color & light book.
I feel like color & light offered a well rounded balance of theory, technical information and examples that other books lack and is exhaustive.

The composition and narrative book is a by-the-numbers text dump of golden ratio, rule of thirds, dark foreground, light background type stuff and offers no examples from Greg Rutkowski himself via thumbnails/sketches or other studies to show practical examples.

Framed Ink 1 & 2, Creative Illustration by Loomis and Edgar Paynes composition of outdoor painting all offer much more.

3DTotal back to their usual low quality books.

Whitout tracing what do younthink is the best way to paint from a digital image that you create/control (AI or not).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434502
You have to fudge the dimensions since all the images are squares, but that’s not too tough. I find it’s better not to do an underdrawing since a lot of the aspects of each AI image are kind of nonsense. So I find the most success with painting directly onto an undercoated painting. Like really the best way to make the AI images into paintings is to heavily HEAVILY draw with the paint. It’s almost similar to plein air painting if you’ve done some of that. You homogenize details in a similar fashion. I’d say if you want to get better at translating the AI images into oil paintings next summer you should get out and do some plein air work. That’s how I feel doing them, it’s not necessarily useful painting from photos to practice for them since the AI is never as precise as a photo

>>6432923
Ok, but what if I ask it to make a superhero for example. Lets say that the training data was limited and only contained pictures of spiderman, batman and superman. If I showed a child what all of these are, explained what they do, and then asked the kid to make me a new superhero, the kid would associate characteristics like superpowers and shiny spandex with superheroes and make me original superhero. It is still derivative, but if I asked the same from Stable Diffusion, it will give me spiderman wearing black cape with superman logo on it. It is mishmash of the characters and some of the generations would contain just weird looking superman, thus copying the source material. This will keep happening because the AI model does not learn like human, it just sees images and names given to them, while humans can understand characteristics and can know more then just the images themselves. In this case it would not be actual copyright infringement, but you get the point. Even if you dont ask it to make Mickey the Mouse, it will still have tendency to sometimes create Mickey the Mouse. Also lot of the models are kind of trained by your output. Like for example if some cloud imagegen makes you 5 images and you choose the best one looking, that app will take that image and conclude that this is the best one out of them, so it will then use it as reference and learn better from it. This is also the reason why ChatGPT is better then GPT-3 despite being smaller mode. GPT-3 is just fed crapped data from the internet, while ChatGPT is thought trough human interaction, and then that human interaction fed into another AI that then trains the ChatGPT and so on. Quite complicated pipeline of teaching, which is why it is superior to GPT-3 in almost all cases.

>>6433048
Code? Haha, anon, anon. I don't need to look at the code when the broad strokes of how image generation models work is freely explained in several places all over the web, easily and democratically accessible to everyone :)
>When "training" the ML algorithm on images, they are lossily compressed down into a lower dimensional set of data and stored in the dataset wholesale, and can be brought back nearly completely unchanged minus some loss of detail due to the compression- a.k.a. encoding and decoding
>each and every image is stored in what is called a latent space or manifold as a data point consisting of x amount of coordinates
>additionally, the space between all of the original image data points are all interpolations of the original images
In summary, datasets are comprised entirely of the images they are trained on and interpolations of the same. When you prompt, you are not creating a new image, you are pulling up an already created image from the latent space, similar to image search. Let me reiterate so that you understand- EVERY SINGLE POSSIBLE IMAGE IS ALREADY INSIDE THE DATASET AND YOU CANNOT CREATE ANYTHING OUTSIDE OF THAT.

Image generation algorithms don't create anything truly new.
(You) are not an artist. You are a glorified web searcher navigating the latent space through the usage of keywords, nothing more and nothing less.

>>6367918
Depends on the colors and obviously on the pigment, let's just say that even on artist grade gouache they're very liberal with their lightfastness grading. Traditional gouache was never meant to be archival, it doesn't form a film once it dries, it's chalky and gets dirty fast unless you put it under glass, it's was meant for illustrators to quickly turn their artwork, photograph it for publishing and forget about it.
General speaking you should worry about the pinks but there are colors that people not suspect like raw sienna and yellow ochre, they will get grayer, unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Even acrylic will shift, I have Golden Fluid Yellow Ochre and it shifted to gray months later. Any color that looks saturated and vibrant won't stay that way for long.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6367918
>Is artist grade Gouache worth it?
Yes. You'll get more pigment, smoother grind, better flow, single-pigment colours (better mixing), less fillers (more vibrant). Schmincke is great, and I can wholly recommend. Just get a few tubes of artist-grade instead of a bunch of chinesium.

>I also want to start painting with acrylic. Do it need any special medium like oil paint or just apply directly on canvas?
Water-soluble, so thinning with water works. You'll only need mediums if you want to thin it a ton, since super-thinned paint films are not necessarily durable. Other than that you can pretty much paint on anything. It's essentially coloured plastic.

There's like a million mediums that you won't need but that could be nice, like thickeners, thinners, drying time extenders, crackling, more shine, less shine, flow improvers, etc. You can make a frankenpaint to your specific liking if you really want to tinker with it.

>>6368450
As said in last thread, Mont Marte probably does not manufacture their own stuff and commission random (see: cheapest) manufacturer to make stuff they just repackage. Sometimes you can get decent stuff, but it really is playing art supply gacha.

HIMI Jelly Gouache is significantly better, and honestly a pretty decent quality paint. I would recommend Holbein, if that's available in your neck of the woods.

>>6368722
>unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Holbein, WN, Schmincke Horadam, and M. Graham all make Gouache without the addition of whiteners, relying on pure pigment density to get opacity. Any of these will work. It's notable that Holbein is by far the cheapest, at least in EU, and Schmincke pigment is very finely ground so it's less opaque than the others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6372118
chalk/marble dust (can extend pigments in oil; use for making paint transparent for glazing in oil; traditional glue chalk ground is less expensive than ready-made acrylic ground and dry components store longer; use as opacifier in gouache)
rabbit skin glue/hide glue (used for grounds, sizing; distemper medium; glue for attaching canvas to board)
metal point (small piece lasts very long; brass can be found for free, or buy/find wire that lasts many life times over; some can fit into a clutch pencil; can coat scrap wood with chalk and or some other ground of your choice in weak glue size and reuse board for scrap drawings, by recoating or scraping)
charcoal powder (can be made for free; decent for ink with suitable binder ground finely; good for paint; use for tracing; many other uses)
egg (yolk and pigment for egg tempera, good for lean underpainting for oil paint or as a cheap and durable paint, don't need entire yolk; can make water-miscible paint by adding to oil paint, thin and clean with water instead of solvents; glair, made by whipping egg white and letting liquid separate from foam, can be used as paint or ink binder; adjust strength with distilled water; can be dried by pouring in a shallow container and letting sit, dissolve again by water; supposedly aged wet, not too tightly sealed glair is better; can be modified by adding honey or sugar etc; used in some varnish recipes; can be use in metal point grounds)

>>6372834
None if you use inks, if not then the film isn't strong enough to adhere to the other layers, should be fine if you're just staining the paper. Use gesso, it will create blooms like watercolor.

Too much water will upset the balance and spread the acrylic polymer too thinly so the molecules can't reconnect properly to form a stable film. Instead you should dilute with an acrylic medium, which is essentially the same as the paint but without the color pigment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375078
if lead is only a trace element in zinc, imagine how little is in titanium wtth 2-5% zinc. painting with cadmium colors is so much more dangerous at that point.
there's a number of inert pigments that are mostly transparent in the average layer of oil paint you can add to make any pigment more transparent.
calcium carbonate (chalk, egg shells, marble, limestone), silica (crushed glass, pumice, silica-rich sand, quartz). calcium carbonate is safer because silica can damage lungs much more. make a paint mixing the transparent pigment with oil to a consistency you like and add it to your tube paint, or add chalk directly and add oil if it is too lean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375089
>By the way, just HOW dangerous is Lead white if you don't grind it yourself? For example are you in trouble if you get it on your skin while painting?
Not in quantities you'd use if it happens a couple of times, but over time you could get yourself in trouble. Lead doesn't really leave your body basically ever once it gets in. By itself, anyway: you can get rid of most of it with Dimercaprol.

If you get it in your food somehow, either by having it in your fingers (Even if it's so little as to not show clearly) or clothes or whatever, that's actually bad. That's why it's recommended to use gloves (Nitrile only: Latex can get dissolved by oil/solvents) and to never eat/drink while in the studio if working with lead white.

Mostly it's a case of "better safe than sorry", but there's genuine long-term health risks that many underestimate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

>>6394737
it's not an alternative to thinners. it's more of an alternative to fluid and gel mediums like sunthickened linseed oil or maroger medium. while thinners lower the oil content, fluid and gel mediums increase the oil content.
one should not use too much thinner because pigments lose binder.
one should not use too much fluid/gel medium because the pigments have too much binder and can cause problems like wrinkling or yellowing depending on the medium.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6399981
G pen is good option if you don't like fineliner. Maru nibs is an option for thinner lines. Dip pen need a lot of practice and kinda messy at first. Stick with Japanese brands.
Also try to use brush and ink, the only problem is they can't really use waterproof ink, otherwise it's pretty flexible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6399981
Brushes and brush pens can be a bit difficult to get used to since you feel much less contact with the surface, but they're a lot of fun. Definitely the most versatile mark-making wise, but it takes a bit of practice to be able to do very fine detail work with them.
Pic related is great since you can control how much ink is loaded on it for drybrush effects and stuff, unlike the Pentel Pocket Brush which is always wet (which makes it a bit more difficult to handle, too).
Dip pens aren't bad choices either, but they also take some getting used to. Just wanted to mention brushes since I feel like they're a bit overlooked these days which is a shame.
Waterproof ink gives brushes a shorter lifespan, but it's not that big of a deal. Pen nibs break and brushes eventually lose their point, but you'll still probably go through them much slower than fineliners.

>>6404987
to clarify
i wasn't talking about watercolor. i meant that even for drawings in dry media i only use pure cotton paper, (but not watercolor cotton paper.) if you explain to buyers of watercolor that something is made of cotton, that's simply expected, especially if the buyer has been in the market for buying watercolor works.
i go beyond what is expected when it comes to materials. for oil painting, the standard is simply to use tube paints, with titanium as the white, over acrylic gesso. i grind from dry pigments, use the best lead white available, and use lead oil ground with the same lead white.
it's not merely an issue of the work fading or deteriorating in 10 years or in their lifetime either. as there are practices and materials that i admit are more archival, but are simply not as beautiful, prestigious, or expensive. aluminum panels, mdf, and plywood are very stable, but are not as inspiring as a joined solid wood panel with hand cut butterfly keys. when it comes to works of art, i consider the support as part of the art, so they must be beautiful as well.
or some materials might outlast others in a few hundred years, but the more available materials are good enough.

posts.com:
>>6415758
there are illustrations of both in use or separately.
palette is good for mixing various tones and making the range of movement more efficient in painting. it also means the paint is somewhat more paste-like. mixtures from the paste can be thinned down with water or more medium, or painted dry thinly. i notice that palettes were generally smaller, because the mixes were simpler and they painted differently colored parts separately, and that the familiar kidney shaped palette became more common later.
shells and bowls are good for fluid paints. the ribs of the shells or the rim of the bowl makes it easy to remove excess moisture from the brush. the bowl shape also means that moisture evaporates slower. one can make different mixes in separate shells but this can be wasteful since you often only need a small amount of each especially since tempera is painted very thinly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6415075

The sets are bad, you're paying a lot for hues that don't play well together.

Only get the SKETCH markers, not the Classic or Ciao. Start with a cool/neutral/warm gray set depending on your style and needs, they can be used as a base with other hues.

Then buy a set of singles with similar color intensities and ID's. Check this guide to make sense of the ID system: https://markernovice.com/copic/copic-numbering

If you're going for realism you're not going to want all the intense candy shades, plus that the hue samples usually look lighter than they'll end up on your paper/pad after several strokes, and a lot of the really lighter shades (X000 etc) can be used to mix with other hues for great effect.

So for a range of blues you might want B21 Baby Blue, B91 Night Blue, B37 Antwerp Blue, B61 Light Hydrangea, instead of the intense ones like B29 Ultramarine, B16 Caynine Blue or B06 Peacock Blue. You can easily get by with a set of 3-4 in each hue range, some skintones, some ultralights, which might amount to 20 or so markers total. A lot cheaper than 72 goofball hues that don't blend well.

You'll get a blender with a gray set but it's not what you think, blending is done by carefully connecting two adjacent hues and not with the blender marker, it's more of an FX thing that'll wet your strokes and turn them abit watercolory.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6426165
For dry drawing media, I use a silver point. My favorite surface is fine Carrara marble dust that is mixed with Dutch lead white which has been ground in vinegar and washed, sometimes tinted with other pigments. For darker lines, some pumice or quartz. For the glue, I choose parchment size mixed with a solution of potash alum.
For the ink to use with natural quill, I take the shavings of red sandalwood or brazilwood and heat it gently in well water, which afterwards is mixed with gum arabic and a pinch of potash alum. I add a drop of clove oil as a preservative.

Doesn't smudge too badly yet still cleans up with both a Faber-castell dust-free eraser for large areas and an eraser shield + prismacolor magic rub for details.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428703
I can't see any of those videos, only the thumbnails because I don't have an Instagram account, but it looks like he uses a fair bit of line weight.
Fineliners are alright and very straightforward for a beginner to use since they always have a single constant width but they won't get you natural line variation, you'll need to manually thicken the line by drawing over it. Their lines can feel very mechanical otherwise, which is only natural considering they're like a disposable version of technical drawing pens.
Fineliners don't shatter under your hand or anything, but they tend to be inconsistent and start having ink flow problems with time, requiring you to hold them very vertically to keep working. The problem is compounded if you happen to be heavy-handed, so if you think that might end up a problem it might be a good idea to pick up Uni-pins instead since they have very durable tips.
But Microns are perfectly well-loved pens as far as their type goes. If you're in for even and consistent lines it's what fineliners will give you.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6428739

ty anon, im still a little confused and looking for direction.

I just wanna try doing some manga style with dynamic line weight, whats a good starting point in terms of pens for learning anime/manga

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428775
Mangaka mainly use dip pens (pic rel), but they're difficult to control and can be a bit hard to find. Bristle brush pens and proper brushes have the most line variation and they're what's behind most of those 熱血 crazy-looking thick lines in drawings by animators like Umakoshi and Hayama. They're also very difficult to control. The difficulty can be a good thing if you want to challenge yourself and train your dexterity, but it could get frustrating for a beginner.
Felt tip brush pens are comparatively really easy to control and you can still get good line variety out of them. I've never used the Micron one but it's probably fine.
A lot of manga artists do use fineliners, but it's usually for details, hatching or speech bubbles. Maru nibs produce similarly thin lines, but they can thicken a bit if you press harder. You can still get super delicate lines out of a pen or brush if you're skilled enough, Akihito Yoshitomi does a lot of detailed machine drawings with dip pens on YouTube if you're interested in watching someone ink in real time.
That's not to say nobody ever inks mainly with fineliners, and I think they were common in shoujo manga in the 2000s. They're very popular with people who draw anime-style illustrations on social media and can be very convenient to work with. They eventually worm their way into a lot of people's workflows, so there's no harm getting some experience with them now if you want to. I think with inking it's definitely a matter of trying a lot of things and seeing what suits you.
Whatever you end up with, I hope you have fun, Anon.

>>6428967
Tried out SG Pen and the Ink Brush, wasn't close to it. So I made this custom brush from a hodge podge of a bunch of brush materials I cannibalized.

I'm not particularly skilled at art, and especially at anime so sorry for the bad drawing. This was to see if I could get close to the original. It was drawn in 1600x2000 then cropped down mainly with the brush size between 12, 16, 20, 24, and 32 depending on what the line thickness is. It's not a good brush for a single line drawing. Instead, you'll have to draw over your lines multiple times to get it to be thick. Keep it light and fast for the "skippy" thin lines. I highly suggest holding your pen either the way Nagabe holds his pen for solid lines and a looser grip for the skippy ones.

https://files.catbox.moe/1ndnwq.sut

posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

Recommended watching:
https://youtu.be/YVAtRojlCS8

Unrelated but what's up with Kevin Finch's pencil handle? It's taped?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6371401
You mean David Finch? The extra girth makes it easier to hold in general. You can hold it with a more relaxed grip or since it is soft, grip it tight without much strain on your hand. This helps to ease cramping from long sessions. It also makes it a bit easier to control of the tip of the pencil.

if you haven't tried the memorization technique, now would be a good time to try it, especially if you're going for simpler studies like for the features.

Make a study
Put away the reference / previous drawing
Draw it again

This will really help the shapes you are studying in Morpho come out in your imaginative drawing

>>6378026
I have the opposite problem, I took a painting class years ago and can only fix things or add detail by reshaping blobs of "paint". My skills have degraded from absence and I'm playing catchup, but my eyes are still ok. I'd like some help on that, but for your problem:

Usually a person has a preference for what kind of style of painting they want, even if they aren't consciously thinking about a certain era of painting. Here are some things to keep in mind while painting:
Do you like it when it looks like you painted it, or do you want to hide it?
Are little details fun or annoying? How about highlights?
There are many ways to make a focal point, which way do you like?

And when you've figured this out, you bend more towards that direction. Since this is the master study thread, you eyeball the art movements on wikipedia or something and say, "that one". For example, someone who doesn't enjoy painstaking detail and wants a painterly look, but likes little flourishes may study impressionist artists.

I know this was posted a while ago but given how complicated the original seems to be, how did you go about starting this study? I still stumble over my own feet when doing master studies of complex work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6400090
spend quite some time doing line art
then paint all the big shape first squint my eyes till it has similar value and color contrast (since I don't try to make it the exact color from the rei one)
when both are done the rest is just mindless zooming in and filling/rendering all the small stuff following the line while zooming out to double-check the big picture with rei one
then paint over the line and redraw some of it
notice that rei is using a different technique here with clean line art and sticking to it so the edge is cleaner and can change line art color a lot. which is hard for me to do since the ref is kinda blurry and I'm lazy so I draw loosely then paint over and redraw some of the line art

>>6427376
It feels really pedantic at first but you need be able to copy things exactly. When other artists do something successfully, the copying skill will let you figure out how to do it for yourself, so it unlocks a lot of learning to be able to do it right. You are already starting to get the even more important thing though, which is that exact copying forces you to develop your ability to see.

posts.sub: What's the difference between "sketching" and "line art"?
posts.com:
Like, when I'm drawing, I usually just pick the pencil tool (Gpen) and... draw the figure and stuff, then I just make another layer down and start coloring.

posts.name: Anonymous

Sketch is messy and undefined
Lineart is cleaned up sketch with no color added

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: bump

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6433227

anon above literally answered your question

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6432333
It mostly boils down to mindset and tool use; gestural, free form approaches and soft leads will be what you tend to see with sketching, whereas lineart tends to see very deliberate stroke work and inks. Fundamentally though, you're using lines in either case to describe a view, and you can very well do both at the same time if you know how to approach that. They can absolutely overlap and playing around with various approaches can help you get there if you want.

Personally, I just stopped bothering about the distinction and kind of do both as needed to streamline my process and also get the best of both worlds, so to speak. If a sketch is neat enough it doesn't need to be mechanically traced over, and they often carry a quality to them you wouldn't get otherwise.

She is currently traveling around the Archipelago in a van alongside numerous underpaid interns. trying to find enemies she can fight for her hit reality show.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Previous thread: >>6403987

Some resources:
/asg/, our stylistic sister-thread series for those focused more on illustration >>>/ic/asg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.
>All unsolicited story/series proposals must have a full creative team on board. Writer-only proposals will not be reviewed.

Image comics ( https://imagecomics.com/ )
>Image Comics only publishes creator-owned material. They do not contract creators; they’re only interested in publishing original content for which you would retain all rights.
>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:

posts.name: Garlic Salt
posts.com:
>>6433538
Ok that's fair. But I'd argue that REAL art is immune to ill effects of AI. Real art is not commercial art. People who are having their illustration or digital art jobs taken from them have already forsaken the essence of art and are simply craftsmen.

AI is simply not predictive. It needs datasets to be told what to create. It can only create aesthetics based off its datasets. Real artists are the ones that create something new. In a sense, that is how Art, with a capital "A", is defined. And anyone who posits that AI "learns" and "creates" something new doesn't understand what real art is.

Lastly, any real, traditional artists who has their art "stolen" wouldn't care. The AI can only make a digital facsimile of their physical art and anyone who would be a customer of the real artist wouldn't be interested in a digital facsimile.

The sky is falling on the internet for internet "artists." But they probably only make up a small percentage of everything and everyone that could be considered "art" or "artists."
